channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Car Bombings Kill Scores Across Iraq
item.description: As Iraqis on Saturday celebrated Id al-Fitr, the holiday that marks the end of Ramadan, a string of car bombs struck in mostly Shiite neighborhoods, killing more than 60 people, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Nine car bombs struck around Baghdad, the capital.

item.title: U.S. Drone Kills 2, Yemen Officials Say
item.description: An American drone strike killed two people believed to be militants in southern Yemen on Saturday, making it the ninth such strike in two weeks.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: For Iraqis, Some Relief Amid Violence: It’s Only 108°
item.description: Amid deadly explosions, Iraqis see cooler weather — average highs fell to 109 degrees in July compared with 115 last year — as a small gesture from God.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Iraqis at an amusement park in Baghdad. Average high temperatures fell to 109 degrees in July.

item.title: Birth of a Palestinian City Is Punctuated by Struggles
item.description: The apartments are said to be selling well in Rawabi, a Palestinian city being constructed from the ground up in the West Bank, but paying for the city itself has not been easy.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rawabi under construction in the West Bank, on Thursday.

item.title: Pitting Heaven and Earth in a Fierce Andean Rite
item.description: The Blood Festival high in the mountains of Peru brings together an unlikely pair in the bullring, with a condor the guest of honor.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Many in Coyllurqui think the condor has divine status.

item.title: Melikhovo Journal: At Chekhov’s Estate, a Pastoral Literary Shrine Belies a Turbulent Century
item.description: A museum dedicated to the great Russian writer Anton Chekhov is also a reflection of a few determined individuals who toiled to preserve his memory.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Chekhov’s country estate, which he bought at age 32, is where he wrote “The Seagull” and many other works.

item.title: Off the Shelf: In ‘Story of My People,’ Recalling an Industry (and Way of Life)
item.description: Edoardo Nesi, a former businessman turned author, tells the story of the textile industry of Prato, Italy, in a memoir filled with musings as finely woven as his company’s woolens.
item.dc:creator: By FRED ANDREWS

item.title: Northern Ireland Police Vow to Pursue Militants
item.description: The police chief of Northern Ireland vowed to imprison Protestant militants after scores of them attacked and wounded 56 officers protecting a parade.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A protester pushed a garbage bin that was set on fire on Friday during clashes with police in Belfast, Ireland.

item.title: Keeping Score: Edgy Is the Crown of the Hit Kings
item.description: Ichiro Suzuki may soon join the 4,000-hit club. His first name, when translated into English, is “most cheerful boy,” but close watchers know that his demeanor is a little more complicated.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN HOFFMAN
item.media:description: Isao Harimoto, left, the only player to top 3,000 hits in Japan, with Ichiro Suzuki, who is nearing 4,000 hits between Japan and the major leagues.

item.title: Lawless Sinai Shows Risks Rising in Fractured Egypt
item.description: In the five weeks since Egypt’s military ousted the Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, the endemic violence here has spiraled into something like an insurgency.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:credit: Narciso Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Christian church's gate in El Arish, in Sinai, was chained shut recently.

item.title: U.S. Condemns Sri Lanka Deaths
item.description: In a statement, the United States called for an investigation of the fatal shooting of three civilians by the Sri Lankan military.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Opinion: How to Read Afghanistan
item.description: American soldiers need help understanding the veiled meanings behind the stories of their allies and enemies.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA M. GEZARI

item.title: Opinion: Marx’s Lesson for the Muslim Brothers
item.description: Lessons for Egypt from the French Revolution of 1848.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By SHERI BERMAN

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Colombia: A Clash on the Border
item.description: Colombia’s Ministry of Defense said Friday that Colombian rebels were responsible for killing an Ecuadorean Army officer and wounding a soldier during a border skirmish on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: In Cairo Camps, Protesters Dig in and Live On
item.description: Two camps in Cairo set up by supporters of the ousted Egyptian president, Mohamed Morsi, have become the front lines in a dangerous stalemate with the military-installed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Narciso Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: A couple who support Egypt’s ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, married Thursday at a protest camp near Cairo University.

item.title: U.S. to Reopen 18 of 19 Closed Embassies
item.description: Most of the American embassies closed this month because of worries about potential terrorist attacks will reopen on Sunday, the State Department said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Pollution Economics
item.description: China tries a market fix for its dirty air.
item.dc:creator: By DIRK FORRISTER and PAUL BLEDSOE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Killing Lions, Buying Bombs
item.description: Tens of thousands of animals are killed each year, with poachers’ profits often being funneled to terrorist groups.
item.dc:creator: By JOHAN BERGENAS, RACHEL STOHL and OCHIENG ADALA

item.title: President Moves to Ease Worries on Surveillance
item.description: President Obama sought to take control of the surveillance debate, releasing a legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more scrutiny of National Security Agency programs.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Journalists in Syria Face Dangers of War and Rising Risk of Abduction
item.description: The Committee to Protect Journalists has reported at least 14 journalists who are missing or have been abducted, but the total number of kidnappings is believed to be much higher.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Florence Aubenas spoke last month at a gathering for Didier François and Édouard Elias, fellow French journalists who disappeared near Aleppo, Syria.

item.title: Mexican Tied to Killing of D.E.A. Agent Is Freed
item.description: Rafael Caro Quintero, a drug kingpin convicted of masterminding an American’s death, was unexpectedly released from prison on Friday after his conviction was overturned.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:description: Rafael Caro Quintero, shown in 2005, had served 28 years in prison.

item.title: Chilean President Apologizes for Census
item.description: President Sebastián Piñera apologized for serious mistakes in the nationwide census last year, which, despite intense efforts, failed to survey over 9 percent of the population.
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: Kerry and Hagel Meet With Their Russian Counterparts
item.description: A day of high-level meetings yielded little definite accomplishments, underscoring the many unresolved remaining issues between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Inquiry Focuses on BBC Severance Payments
item.description: The police in Britain opened an investigation after an audit found departing executives from the British Broadcasting Corporation received more than they were entitled to.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY and RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Kenyan Inquiries Find No Sign of Explosion in Airport Fire, President Says
item.description: President Uhuru Kenyatta said initial investigations had found that “this was a simple fire gone bad.”
item.dc:creator: By REUBEN KYAMA
